content.description:
It may be short, but it has three cruxes.  This route is the epitome of the TR = boulder problem. 

  Start just left of the corner, step right to the corner.  Move left to the flake.  Work right under the overlap, until a big move scores you the obvious jug.  The final crux is re-tabling up onto the jug.
content.protection: Ha ha ha!  The TR setup is funky, too.
content.location: Up the gully left of Reclining Tower, on the prominent corner of the wall to the left.  Perhaps 50 feet from the trail along the top.

content.description: Climb the sharp flakes left of the pine tree located on the wall. Some interesting chimney and mantels to follow. Angle left on the path of least resistance.

One of the nicer routes in this grade.  No chimneying required. 

  Stem up the cleft at the base, arriving at a ledge with a monster pine tree on the right.  Work you way up the dihedral formed between the Tower and the cliff.  The crux comes in the middle, about where you can look through the hole in the tower to the Lake. 

  At the top you have several options: scramble up on the boulder to the left (best place to set a TR), walk back away from the cliff (easiest), or bust a move up the crack in the headwall to your right and finish on top of the tower (one 5.6-5.7 move).
content.protection: Nuts & hexes are plenty.  You could use one piece to 4".
content.location: On the left (south) side of the Reclining Tower.

content.description: Climb the face right of the arete.
content.location: North of the big pine tree (Pine Tree Crack) and around the corner (arete).

content.description:
Climb steep lower corner (crux) to large platform at 20'. Continue on arete to top of tower.

 There's a 5.6 variation mentioned in Swartling/Mayer: Start on North Side. At 20', traverse left to large platform. Continue on arete to top of tower.
content.location: Look for the arete right of the big pine tree (Pine Tree Crack) at the lowest point of the wall.

content.description: A few strenuous moves in a hand crack to a bear hug on a giant pine tree take you up to a sharp and exposed arete.
content.protection: Nuts and Hexs. Run out on the easier terrain above.
content.location: Find short crack leading to the giant pine tree on a ledge about 15 feet off the ground. Pass the tree on the right and head straight up the arete.

content.description: Climb inside corner and deep awkward crack, which is wide enough at the crux to be considered a small chimney. Easy to protect until you reach the crux. A small lateral crack is hidden out of view within the small chimney and it can be hard to reach from the stance below, but it's a bomber small nut placement. The crux consists of making the committing and very exposed move out left before moving up into the crack. After another step up or two, there's a large handhold and a good placement for a #3 Camelot if you think you still need it, since at that point your one step below being able to grab the top of the tower.
content.protection: Mostly nuts, a tricam or two and a #3 Camelot.
content.location: Pretty obvious line up the wide inside corner on the north side of the tower. I usually rap from the top which leaves good anchor in place to clip and then belay your second on up. There's a gully access just north of the tower, but it's steep and usually quite muddy.

content.description:
Start by climbing the inside corner on the left side of the wall. The guide books differ on the finish - both are worth doing. (This route joins with Two Flakes at the 25' ledge.)

 Per Swartling/Mayer - climb crack and V-chimney 25' to ledge on right. Retable to next ledge. Continue up and right to third ledge, then to top.

 Per Knower - climb the deep inside cleft and continue to the top (finishing more straight up and a little left of S/M).

 This is an unnamed 5.7 in both Knower and Swartling/Mayer guide books. I decided to give it a name since another unnamed 5.7 is just a few feet left of this one.
content.location: On the left side of the main wall, in the corner formed by the main wall on the right and the small buttress that juts out on the left.

content.description:
On the buttress just left of the main wall. Climb east corner to base of small tower. Balance up left onto south corner. Climb corner to top of tower, then step over gap and climb short wall above. 

 This is an unnamed 5.7 in both Knower and Swartling/Mayer guide books. I decided to give it a name since another unnamed 5.7 is just a few feet right of this one. The route description is right out of S/M.
content.location: Look for the small buttress that juts out from the left side of the main wall at the Reclining Tower area.

content.description: A sweet line between routes 7 and 8.Crack in middle of lower wall, hang up and right, work back left to good ledge, then power back right to top. (Note: a much tougher line is present if one does not work towards ledge. I'm confidant it is doable for some other DL Hardman.)
The Reclining Tower is a fine formation to spend a day at, containing moderate to challenging climbs.  The formation sees little traffic, so you'll likely have the place to yourself.
